nodes.bodyText: I would remove this commented out line.

Now that the bug is fixed, can it ever return a Java class name? I'd be tempted to just pare this down to simply "Returns the type of o as a string."

@tfmorris: the question you raise is far more complex, from what I see. In Issue «
true.type() return « java.lang.Boolean » and not « boolean »
#2510 », you will find some discussion on that, but here's a table I did:



Expression
Result
Expected result

Because in the code, we have this: return v.getClass().getName(), we can never be sure of all the value that can be returned. I guess the only thing we can be sure it's that it's going to be a string…
                } else if (v instanceof EvalError) {
                    return "error";
                } else {
                    return v.getClass().getName();
                }

I think we should close this issue, and maybe open another one on how to return a type from an object. By closing this issue, we finalize the type() function with basic datatypes.
For this particular change you suggest: « The string 'error' is returned if the value can't be evaluated"; », I wouldn't write that because I don't believe it's accurate. Imagine the case of use type(value), where value contains a previous stored error. But this discussion should be in issue « type(an error) should return the string "error" like the code was designed to do but is buggy #2562 ». Do you share this opinion?
Regards, Antoine
Marking this as resolved. As discussed elsewhere, evaluation errors happen before ever reaching this function.

@tfmorris: Is what to be understood here is that type(an error) will only return "error" for certains types of errors? And if so, shouldn't it be documented which error are trap and which one are « reraised »?
Regards, Antoine
